awd_titl_txt: Determining the Source of Methane in Arctic Ocean Waters Adjacent to Subsea Permafrost
awd_abstract_narration: Methane is a potent greenhouse gas that is present in large amounts in frozen soils and marine sediments in the Arctic. Both natural and anthropogenic climate change are influencing the methane dynamics in the Arctic Ocean, through thawing of subsea permafrost as well as the decreasing sea-ice extent; several recent investigations have documented seemingly elevated methane concentrations in seawater and releases of methane to the atmosphere associated with both of these processes. Release of stored methane can lead to further warming and then to further methane releases in a reinforcing cycle. Both subsea permafrost thaw and sea-ice melt can influence several methane reservoirs such as the stability of ancient methane stored within and below sediments as well as the production of methane by microorganisms both in the seafloor in recently deposited sediments and thawed permafrost and in subsurface ocean waters associated with phytoplankton blooms. Given the diverse sources of methane to ocean waters and the atmosphere in the continental margins of the Arctic Ocean, it is currently unknown which source is contributing most of the observed methane in Arctic waters and thus how the magnitude of this methane source may change. Measurements of the natural radiocarbon content of methane dissolved in ocean waters and sediments can be used to identify its source. For example, methane emitted from seeps and clathrate hydrates is radiocarbon-free, methane formed in recently deposited anoxic sediments or in the subsurface ocean as a result of phytoplankton blooms contains more modern levels of radiocarbon, and degrading permafrost is of Pleistocene age (27,000-43,000 years old). The work proposed here will aim to elucidate these sources through natural radiocarbon measurements of methane dissolved in ocean waters and sediments collected during transects across the continental margin of the Beaufort Sea. The major challenge associated with measuring the natural radiocarbon content of methane dissolved in seawater is collecting enough methane carbon for a quantitative Accelerator Mass Spectrometry (AMS) analysis. Previously published procedures have recently been modified enabling the extraction and collection of methane from approximately 10,000 liters of seawater in less than two hours. These new procedures will enable roughly 100 samples to be collected during a one week oceanographic expedition. Measured horizontal and vertical distributions of the natural radiocarbon content of methane dissolved in ocean waters will determine how the source of methane changes from the coast to the open ocean and from the seafloor to the sea surface. These methane isotopic distributions will also provide a solid test of the hypothesis that the aerobic oxidation of methane will provide a counterbalancing feedback removing the increased quantities of methane leaving the seafloor before it reaches the atmosphere. Graduate and undergraduate students will be involved in the entire scientific process with opportunities not only in their home lab, but also with visits to other facilities. The investigators will leverage firmly established pathways with the University of Rochester and the Rochester Museum and Science Center to promote educational programs within the Rochester City School District to serve underrepresented minority K-12 students.

por.por_cntn:
The continental margins in the Arctic Ocean are potentially massive sources of methane.  Subsea permafrost and methane clathrate hydrates are found in this region and, when thawed or decomposed, are hypothesized to release large quantities of this greenhouse gas to the overlying waters and atmosphere.  In addition, the Arctic Ocean is currently experiencing a rate of warming approximately twice the global average, potentially contributing to the thawing and destabilization of these massive methane reservoirs.  However, it has also been shown that the impact of methane sourced from destabilizing hydrates and thawing subsea permafrost on modern climate is likely to take place across timescales of millennia or more, not centuries (Archer et al. 2009; Biastoch et al. 2011; Ruppel 2011; Schuur et al. 2015), and that microbial oxidation processes strongly remove methane from ocean sediments (Alperin and Reeburgh 1984; Knittel and Boetius 2009; Overduin et al. 2015) as well as from the water column (Mau et al. 2007; Myhre et al. 2016). Understanding the extent to which the shallow Arctic Ocean shelf inventory of seafloor-sourced methane from thawing permafrost and decomposing hydrates is reaching contemporary surface waters, where it can enter the atmosphere and accelerate ongoing natural and anthropogenic climate change, was the aim of this study.  

 

To do so, we measured the natural radiocarbon content of methane dissolved in the waters of the U.S. Beaufort Sea.  Natural radiocarbon measurements of methane can help to distinguish different sources of this gas, with methane derived from thawing permafrost and decomposing hydrates containing ancient amounts of radiocarbon while other sources, such a modern sediments, in-situ aerobic methanogenesis, or diffusion from the atmosphere can have more modern quantities of radiocarbon.  The major methodological challenge is collecting sufficient amounts of natural methane for a high precision radiocarbon analysis; at typical background concentrations of methane in the ocean, this requires methane to be quantitatively extracted from almost 10,000 L of water. We developed a new method which pumps seawater up from depth into a dissolved gas extraction system, which continuously removes the dissolved gases from a constant flow (> 200 liters per min) of water. With negligible contamination, 100s L of dissolved gases are extracted from 20,000 to 40,000 L seawater in 2-3 hr and compressed into a small cylinder for transport from the field to the laboratory. The laboratory preparation of these samples for traditional radiocarbon analyses with an accelerator mass spectrometer is carried out on a flow-through vacuum line which was also developed during this project.  This line purifies, oxidizes, and collects the methane contained in each sample at a high flowrate with high combustion and collection efficiencies, enabling multiple samples to be prepared per day.

 

The results of our natural radiocarbon measurements of methane sampled in waters of 2 to 38 m depth show that methane emitted from the seafloor of Prudhoe Bay, Alaska is decreasingly able to reach surface waters as water column depth increases. Seafloor-sourced methane is decoupled from surface waters at total depths ≥ 28 m, which was demonstrated at the two deepest stations (28 and 38 m depth). At these two stations, the near-seafloor methane samples were observed to have ancient radiocarbon contents, while, by sharp contrast, the surface water samples were found to be of modern radiocarbon age. Interestingly, these depths where no ancient methane was observed in the surface waters are also the depths where subsea permafrost has thawed and is in fact bioavailable to produce methane.  At depths shallower than 28 m, older methane was observed in the surface waters, however, these depths have intact subsea permafrost suggesting that at least some of this ancient methane may have come from terrestrial permafrost which has thawed and transferred its carbon to the ocean via rivers.  In addition to establishing a boundary where methane in bottom waters of this shallow Arctic shelf does not survive to surface waters, this dataset suggests that little to no hydrate-sourced methane is present in this area. In sum, this study asserts that the ancient carbon-sourced methane in Prudhoe Bay is largely not reaching the atmosphere beyond the 28 m isobath.
